The Almond Project

Treehouse California Almonds and one of its third-generation almond growers are proud partners in The Almond Project, a multi-year initiative aimed at advancing more sustainable almond farming methods.

Our Mission

The Almond Project’s mission is to preserve natural resources, enable ecosystem regeneration, protect farming communities, and ensure that there will be nutritionally rich California almonds for generations to come.

This sustainable farming initiative is able to pursue such goals thanks to the contributions of a vibrant coalition of farmers, scientists, brands, technical service providers, processors, and customers.

Soil Health Practices

Project partners are implementing and testing a range of regenerative soil health practices on almond farms in California. They are measuring and comparing outcomes across soil and ecosystem health factors such as water holding capacity and infiltration, carbon sequestration, and ecosystem biodiversity. Key soil health practices include:

Multi-Species Cover Crops

Animal Integration in Cropping Systems

Increased Compost Application

Input Reduction for Ecosystem Health

Why Are We Doing This?

The climate crisis poses a dire threat to almonds and the farmers whose livelihoods depend on them. We believe that healthy soil is key to the longevity of almond farming.

However, practical research has been hard to come by. The Almond Project partners are contributing to our base of knowledge about how to sustain and improve soil health.

In the long term, the Project seeks to provide farmers and food companies with compelling proof points about the benefits of adopting practices that may help to regenerate California’s working lands.

Our Partners

The Almond Project brings together a broad range of almond industry participants, all of whom are advocates for a more resilient and healthy food system and environment and the resiliency of California agriculture.

Join the Project

The Almond Project invites new partners to contribute to our body of research, which aims to support scalable sustainability practices in commercial agriculture in California.

Join The Project Learn More
